Badly-written, lazily-directed and saddled with terrible-pacing, wooden acting and a scattershot plot, Maid in Malaca√±ang is Filipino Film Director Darryl Yap's vanity project whose sole raison d'etre seems be laundering the ignominious reputation of one of history's worst kleptocratic dictators Ferdinand Marcos Sr. along with his equally corrupt family (a reputation surpassed only by Suharto in pilfering his respective nation's coffers).Indeed, the project was concieved with the deposed despot's own unrepentant daughter Senator Imee Marcos serving as its "creative producer". With all of these elements at play, one can't help but think this film is just bad propaganda and self-serving hagiography. It brings nothing new to the table nor does it contribute to the advancement of the moviemaking craft. If that's not bad enough, Yap makes amateurish directorial missteps such as telling the story instead of showing it. The only positive the film possess is the fact the producers clearly spent money on its set pieces. With Maid in Malaca√±ang, Yap ascends to the list of ignominious filmmakers such as Leni Riefenstahl and D.W. Griffith but with far less talent. Yap is certainly no auteur.

Take a 360¬∞ look at the last 72 hours of the Marcoses in the presidential palace at the height of the EDSA Revolution in 1986. Highly controversial due to its subject matter, it gives voice to the infamous family that has never told its most vulnerable stories before. Passionately crafted by its equally controversial director Darryl Yap, this is his first drama film and Viva Films' first major theatrical event in the time of pandemic.Its ensemble cast consists of respectable actors, but special mention to three standout performances: Cesar Montano, who also previously played the hero Jose Rizal in the 90s, has effectively humanized the late Ferdinand Marcos Sr. as a father. The father-and-son confrontation was very powerful, more so that he shared the scene with his real-life son, Diego Loyzaga. Cristine Reyes as the eldest daughter Imee carried the film's tense moments on her shoulders and her indomitable presence brought the entire household together in its darkest hours. Beverly Salviejo utilized her theatrical chops as the housemaid Biday and she balanced all the drama with her genuinely funny antics that in one scene with her fellow maids, you'd see yourself cry then laugh then cry again.This is a family story at its very core, a dramatization of their final hours as a powerful first family and before their lives are changed forever. I like how every chapter incorporates real news footage or context then it portrays how it was like in the palace as these historical moments unfold. The soundtrack captures the mood and makes certain scenes unforgettable. The film evokes the feel of watching a theatrical play with its continuous shots and reliance on dialogue.However, this is in no way a perfect film. While it mainly focuses on the characters' interactions, there are certain parts of conversations that I believe are unnecessary and could've been ommitted. Since it's a period piece, there were some (humorous) utterances more common in our current day and age that it's ridiculous to hear them in 1986. The camera works need more polishing especially in the continuous scenes, there are times when the framing or angle techniques could be a bit distracting to the viewers (and to the actors too). Plus, I would love to see more of Imelda than in the very few scenes she's in.And for the million dollar question: Does the film blatantly revise history as we know it? Well, you'd be disappointed to find this is not the film all them noisy people are claiming it to be. The emotional outbursts on where the family's persecution was coming from could be heavily debated, but these were the family's inner thoughts in the midst of chaos. The controversial Cory scene is simply as it is, aptly symbolizing the 'game' of politics after EDSA.All in all, you'll feel roller-coaster emotions for the characters you've only heard bad things about, and you'll see them in the perspective of the closest people who were actually THERE. In fact, the thing that moved me the most is realizing that they are as real as you and I, and that far from being historians, at least they have finally spoken their truth.And the rest, they say, is history.4/5 ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
